Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effects of the Law on Precarity among Youth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Youth who experience precarity in living arrangements and life experience may have difficulty in the transition to adulthood and in achieving economic stability in later years. Some youths are more subject to precarity than others, thus allowing study of how laws and their interpretation may promote or deter positive outcomes in this population. In addition, policies relevant to this precarity have changed over time, and/or their interpretations have changed, thus creating a natural experiment. This is an under-studied aspect of the transition to adulthood, thus motivating the project that will portray these varied experiences. The project will shed light on how interpretations of laws and the laws themselves can be significant factors in easing the transition to adulthood, or reducing the likelihood of successful assumption of productive adult roles. Findings from the project will help inform state and federal policies to better support youth transitions to adulthood.

This project will use participant observation and in-depth semi-structured interviews to highlight the processes and mechanisms through which some youths more or less easily navigate precarious environments. The project will conduct interviews with 30 youths who experience some degree of precarity, as well as with 30 adults charged with helping them navigate the transition to adulthood. The project will also conduct an additional 25 interviews with state actors assisting in these transitions. Participant observation over a period of several months will allow inferences regarding the variety of contexts relevant to the transition to adulthood for youths subject to precarity. Re-interviews with a subset of youths at a second time point will allow inferences regarding how the relevant processes evolve over time, as well as analysis of key outcomes that have occurred during the interval. Qualitative analyses using Atlas.ti will permit iterative coding of the interview and observational data, allowing both deductive and inductive approaches. Findings will inform key literatures on the sociology of law, the role of state supports of youth, and the transition to adulthood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past ten years, nearly a half-million unaccompanied minors have been apprehended at the U.S.-Mexico border, as violence, human rights violations, and deprivation have triggered outflows from El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala, where teenagers are especially at risk of being targeted by gangs. Unaccompanied minors’ asylum applications increased exponentially during that time from just over 400 to a high of more than 20,000 per year. 

The research supported by this award asks: how do mixed legal frameworks  –where laws that protect minors and exclusionary immigration enforcement laws co-exist – shape the lives of unaccompanied minors and the legal strategies of the immigration attorneys who help them apply for asylum and other forms of humanitarian relief from deportation?

Chiara Galli undertook research in Los Angeles, which is the main destination for unaccompanied minors in the US, comparing the Obama and Trump policy contexts (January 2015- January 2021). She conducted participant observation in non-profit legal aid organizations, shadowing staff as they assisted 78 unaccompanied minors applying for asylum or special immigrant juvenile status (SIJS), a form of relief for children abandoned, abused, or neglected by their parent(s). She also conducted 120 in-depth interviews with immigration attorneys, other advocates, asylum officers, unaccompanied minors, and their family members. Twelve youth interviewees were followed for two years. 

The researcher found that, while unaccompanied minors already faced significant challenges during the Obama administration, their access to legal status was further curtailed by Trump administration policies. The high number restrictive changes, introduced at a rapid pace, transformed the legal context of reception into one characterized by heightened uncertainty. Case outcomes became more difficult to predict as the Trump administration narrowed the interpretation of eligibility criteria for asylum and SIJS, which already under Obama provided limited relief to youths, including those who escaped life-threatening violence. Changes placed unaccompanied minors who turned 18 at risk of “ageing out” of eligibility for relief or special protections. Impact litigation halted or stopped various Trump-era policies. However, while litigation was pending, these changes negatively affected youths and created new strains on legal aid organizations. Attorneys changed their legal strategies to react to Trump-era policies. They found new ways to diversify risk for their young clients by: filing applications more quickly to work against the clock of restrictive changes; applying for more than one type of relief; preparing memos to argue against restrictive changes; and continuing to file cases that would have been likely to win under the Obama-era status quo. Lawyers also frequently updated their young clients, who have very limited understandings of immigration law, about complex policy changes and managed their expectations about the likely outcomes of their cases. Enacting these strategies vastly increased the workload necessary for each youth’s case, taxing already limited resources.

 

The material and psychological toll of heightened uncertainty and prolonged legal limbo, in turn, adversely affected youths’ wellbeing beyond the legal realm. Unresolved cases meant that youths who completed high school were unable to apply for financial aid that would have allowed them pursue higher education. Other unaccompanied minors are unable to focus on school because they need to work to support themselves. While pending asylum applications confer work permits, which allowed youths to access better paid and more stable jobs, youths with pending SIJS cases are not allowed to work. SIJS applicants had more difficulty finding work or were stuck in exploitative jobs in the informal economy. When family members were unable to support them, youths restricted from working legally were more at risk of housing and food insecurity and homelessness.

While they migrate without parents, the vast majority of youths are released to family members while they await the outcomes of their proceedings. Youths’ coming of age and family reunification experiences were gendered. Females were more likely than males to stay in high school and to live with adult family members for longer. For males, work was a chance emancipate themselves from family and live on their own. Conversely, females saw work as a means to contribute to family expenses. Youths reported experiencing both conflict and support at home as they navigated reunification with parents from whom they had long been separated or with relatives they barely knew. It was more common for youths, especially males, to experience conflict with non-parent caretakers. While everyday lives in school, work, and family inevitably went on amidst challenges while applications were pending, unaccompanied minors who won their asylum and SIJS cases experienced emotional and material stability and were able to plan a long term future in the US.

Findings from this study can provide policymakers with insights to enact humane immigration reform and can be used to increase public social scientific literacy about Central American unaccompanied child migration at a time when misinformation is having adverse effects on immigrant communities.
